screens.headline: Your option loses $50 every single day
screens.text: Stock doesn't move. Market closed. You did nothing. Yet your call drops from $500 to $450 overnight. This is theta decay - the silent killer of option buyers. Let's understand it so you can avoid it.

screens.headline: What is Theta (Time Decay)?
screens.text: Theta is the rate at which your option loses value as time passes. Every day closer to expiration = less time for the stock to move = lower time value. Theta accelerates in the final 30 days. At expiration, time value = $0. Always.

screens.headline: Think of it like a melting ice cube
screens.text: You buy a 10-pound block of ice for $100. You plan to sell it when it's most valuable. But it's melting - losing weight every hour, faster as it gets smaller...

reveal_sections.label: Day 1: Ice is 10 lbs, melts slowly
reveal_sections.content: You lose 0.2 lbs per day. Hardly noticeable. You still have 9.8 lbs. Plenty of time to sell it. This is long-dated options (90+ days).

reveal_sections.label: Day 7: Ice is 7 lbs, melting faster
reveal_sections.content: Now losing 0.5 lbs per day. Temperature is rising. You need to sell soon or it'll be worthless. This is 30-day options.

reveal_sections.label: Day 9: Ice is 3 lbs, melting FAST
reveal_sections.content: Losing 1+ lbs per day. In a race against time. Tomorrow it might be 0. This is final week - theta decay is exponential.

reveal_sections.label: This is time decay (theta)
reveal_sections.content: Your option = ice. Expiration = when it's fully melted. The closer you get, the faster it melts. You're in a race against the clock.

cards.definition: Daily rate of time decay (usually shown as negative)
cards.example: Theta = -$0.50 = your option loses $0.50/share per day √ó 100 = $50/day in value. Every. Single. Day.

cards.definition: Time decay speeds up dramatically in final 30 days
cards.example: Option loses $20/week at 60 days out. Loses $50/week at 20 days out. Loses $100+/week in final 7 days. Exponential.

cards.definition: Options decay over weekends even though market is closed
cards.example: Buy Friday, worth less Monday. You lost 2-3 days of time value. Market closed, but the countdown clock never stops.

screens.question: You buy a call on Monday for $500. Stock doesn't move all week. Friday, it's worth $450. Why?
options: Theta decay ate $50 of time value
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! This is pure theta decay. You had 5 less days until expiration, so time value decreased $50. Stock didn't move = no change in intrinsic value. But time value bleeds every day. This is why holding options is expensive.
screens.explanation_wrong: Stock didn't move = intrinsic value unchanged. But you now have 5 fewer days until expiration. That LOST time = lost value. Every day that passes, time value decays. This is theta - the silent option killer for buyers.

screens.question: Which option loses MORE value per day to theta decay?
options: They decay at the same rate
screens.explanation_correct: Right! Short-dated options decay MUCH faster. A 7-day option might lose $30/day. A 90-day option might lose $5/day. The acceleration is exponential. This is why weekly options are dangerous - you're fighting the clock every single day.
screens.explanation_wrong: Theta accelerates as expiration approaches. 90-day option = slow bleed ($5/day). 7-day option = rapid decay ($30+/day). The final week is brutal - you can lose 50% of value even if stock moves in your direction but not fast enough.

screens.question: It's Wednesday. You own calls expiring Friday. Stock moved UP 3% but your calls are FLAT. Why?
options: Delta gains were erased by theta decay
Stock needs to move more than 3%
screens.explanation_correct: This is the trader's nightmare! Stock moved in your favor (+3%), but with only 2 days left, theta decay is MASSIVE (might be $100/day). Your gains from stock movement were completely eaten by time decay. This is why short-dated options are so risky.
screens.explanation_wrong: You experienced the theta trap. Yes, stock went up (+3% = positive delta). But you lost 2 days of time (massive negative theta with 2 days left). When theta > delta, you lose even when you're RIGHT. Lesson: give yourself time!

screens.question: You're choosing between two calls. Same strike, same stock. A) 30 days = $300. B) 90 days = $600. Which fights theta better?
screens.explanation_correct: Smart thinking! The 90-day costs 2x but gives you 3x the time. You have breathing room for your thesis to play out. The 30-day enters rapid decay immediately. For directional trades, paying up for time is often worth it.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think per-day cost: 30-day = $10/day theta burn. 90-day = $6.67/day. Plus, the 30-day enters exponential decay immediately. The 90-day has 60 days of slow decay before acceleration. You're buying TIME to be right.

screens.headline: Theta Decay Visualizer
screens.description: Watch how time value decays as expiration approaches
teaching_points: Notice: Decay is slow at 90 days, then accelerates
The final 30 days is where most time value disappears
Intrinsic value never decays - only time value goes to zero

cards.back: The daily loss of time value as expiration approaches. Shown as negative number (theta = -$0.50 = lose $50/day). Accelerates exponentially in final 30 days.
Buy longer expirations (90+ days), avoid holding through final 30 days, sell winners early (50-100% gain), cut losers fast (-50%). Or become a seller and LET theta work for you.
Never buy options with less than 30 days unless you have a SPECIFIC catalyst (earnings). The decay rate is too fast. Give yourself at least 60 days to be right.

screens.badge_description: You understand time decay and how to fight it!
screens.celebration_message: Awesome! You now know the invisible force that kills most option traders. Next: what happens at expiration - assignment and exercise.
